Summary I am a biochemist with experience in diverse areas of human diseases ranging from ovarian cancer to disorders in lipid metabolism and extracellular matrix metabolism such as obesity, diabetes, female pelvic organ disorder, uterine fibroids. I am interested in applying my skills and enthusiasm in the biotech and pharmaceutical sectors. Specialties:Basic protein analysis techniques (such as western blot, subcellular fractionation, immunoprecipitation, spectrophotometric enzyme assay) basic molecular biology techniques, lipid analysis, apoptosis and cell proliferation assays,analysis of anti-cancer effects of small molecules, handling animal and human tissues/body fluids, tissue culture (both cell line and primary culture). Summary Wei-Shiuen Ng is a Postdoctoral Scholar in the Precourt Energy Efficiency Center at Stanford University. Her recent research focuses on the evaluation of parking pricing and its influence on travel behavior, as well as the development of transportation policies that will reduce energy use and emissions. 
 
Wei-Shiuen holds a Ph.D. in City and Regional Planning from the University of California, Berkeley, a Masters in Environmental Science from Yale University School of Forestry and Environmental Studies and a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Economics and Environmental Management from the University of York. Prior to starting her doctoral program at the University of California, Berkeley, she was a transportation policy analyst at EMBARQ, the World Resources Institute Center for Sustainable Transport in Washington DC. She has previously studied the economic impact of climate change induced sea level rise and has experience in areas of transportation emissions and energy modeling, transportation policy scenarios building, environmental and social impact analysis of motorization, and sustainable urban transportation development in Asia.  
 
Wei-Shiuen is especially interested in solving urban environmental problems through transportation demand management. She hopes to help reduce carbon emissions from the transportation sector and create livable cities though good planning and policy implementation. 
 
Specialties: Climate change economics, energy and transportation scenarios modeling, transportation policy analysis, project management, proposal writing, project planning, budgeting and grant management, stakeholders management Summary Wei-Shiuen Ng is a Postdoctoral Scholar in the Precourt Energy Efficiency Center at Stanford University. Summary I am a postdoctoral scholar at Stanford University. I received the PhD degree from EURECOM/Telecom Paris Tech in 2013, the M.Sc. degree from Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications in 2010, and the B.Sc. degree from Tianjin University in 2007. During 2013, I was a visiting scholar at University of California, Irvine. 
 
I am hardworking, targets-oriented, passionate, and a team player.  
My industry experience includes doing internship at Ericsson, Beijing. 
My research interests include information theory, communication theory and estimation theory, as well as their applications in heterogeneous network, relay network, massive MIMO, big data and bioinformatics. Summary My motto: "shaping the future with research; managing the presence to excellence". 
 
There is one question I ask myself every day: how can I make a real impact on people lives? Scientific research and commitment to leadership are my answers. 
 
Energy is the most important challenge of the next century. I am interested in energy efficiency and new approaches to enable competitive renewable energy sources. In my research, I work with light and matter. I create semiconductor nanostructures specifically designed to be efficient light sources; on a different side, I manipulate and trap light to envision next generation of silicon-based solar cells. I am a physicist by training (PhD in 2010). Right now, my research activity is across physics, materials science, and engineering. The perfect balance between fundamental concepts applied to real devices. I always had a strong interaction with semiconductor industries. I have large experience and ability to design, fabricate and test new materials and device prototypes, developing a new idea from the basic physical principles to an actual implementation. 
 
I am aware that innovation can be made only by a diverse team of people focused on the same goal. Getting the best out of each of us is the most challenging role of a leader. I had the possibility to manage small and large groups of people, achieving unexpected great results, with a large impact on the group members as well as on a large community. 
 
My strengths are: excellent time management, people values and interests evaluation, peer support and consulting, mentoring experience, events organization, tasks organization and coordination. 
 
People I met with think I am action-oriented and collaborative. 
My friends define me as trustworthy and problem solver. 
I consider myself curious and organized. 
 
For more information about me and my projects take a look at my website: Summary My motto: "shaping the future with research; managing the presence to excellence".

Mentor at StartX - Stanford start-up accelerator Chief Organizer TEDxSSCLive January 2015  –  March 2015  (3 months) Catania Area, Italy President of the Association Alumni Scuola Superiore di Catania January 2011  –  December 2014  (4 years) I strongly believe in the give-back idea. I hold my current position also because of my education. This is because I decided to get involved in my alma mater alumni association. This really is a rewarding experience in terms of positive feedbacks, satisfactions for all the organized events, and recognition from the current students.  
 
 
Who we are 
 
130+ alumni of a high-excellence education institution within the University of Catania (Scuola Superiore di Catania). The institution acceptance rate is very low (less than 10%). It provides a full scholarship for all the college years, including lodging in an historical campus (Villa San Saverio). Very high grade average and strict deadlines are required to maintain the scholarship. Attendance of complementary and high-level classes is required, along with a research thesis at the end of the scholarship (in addition to the standard university classes and master thesis). As alumni, we contribute to the education of the current students, create a network of diverse experiences and skills, represent the best output of our alma mater. 
 
 
What we do 
 
We organize scientific seminars and conferences (once a week during the school year) and orientation activities. We mentor current students. We organize social events. 
 
 
My role and responsibilities 
 
As a President, I run and lead the organization of all the events and activities; I interact with the academic and students representatives; I organize an yearly fund-raising campaign to support the Association activities; I interact with all the alumni members to involve, motivate, and support their active participation; I am the administrator of the Association website, Facebook and LinkedIn groups, Twitter and YouTube accounts. Chief Organizer TEDxSSC April 2014  –  October 2014  (7 months) TEDxSSC - Dall'eccezione alla regola (From the exception to the rule) 
 
Leading the entire organization of a TEDx event (100+ guests, 20+ speakers, 18 organizing 
team members, $20k budget). 
 
TED is a world-wide recognized brand ensuring high quality talks, speakers and ideas. As a President of the SSC Alumni Association, along with the Student Association and the academic leaders, we decided to bring TED experience in our institution and community through TEDxSSC. In fact, many of the TEDx values match our institution values (interdisciplinarity, fostering new ideas, spreading innovation and creativity). TEDx mission is to communicate the power of ideas to change attitudes, lives and, ultimately, the world. We want to demonstrate how uncommon ideas and people (the exceptions) can make a real difference, change the world and set a new standard for our everyday life. We have chosen an extremely fascinating theme: “Dall’eccezione alla regola” (“From the exception to the standard”). Our speakers will be unheard local voices as well as known personalities. We will select our list of speakers choosing those people that can tell their personal story as an example of something first considered an exception, then becoming a new standard. iFarm Team program volunteer Stanford University Office of Technology Licensing January 2014  –  June 2014  (6 months) Moving technology form the research lab to everyday life. This is my goal. 
 
I was admitted in the Stanford iFarm program during Winter 2014. The Stanford Innovation Farm Teams Project seeks to improve success and overall efficiency of the commercialization of Stanford-owned inventions while providing an educational experience to iFarm Team participants. Participation in the iFarm Team Project provides individuals with a unique educational experience and opportunity to network in highly competitive industries. Together with my other teammates, we will select one of the Stanford-owned technology and move it to a commercialization stage. I hold my current position also because of my education. This is because I decided to get involved in my alma mater alumni association. This really is a rewarding experience in terms of positive feedbacks, satisfactions for all the organized events, and recognition from the current students.  
 
 
Who we are 
 
130+ alumni of a high-excellence education institution within the University of Catania (Scuola Superiore di Catania). The institution acceptance rate is very low (less than 10%). It provides a full scholarship for all the college years, including lodging in an historical campus (Villa San Saverio). Very high grade average and strict deadlines are required to maintain the scholarship. Attendance of complementary and high-level classes is required, along with a research thesis at the end of the scholarship (in addition to the standard university classes and master thesis). As alumni, we contribute to the education of the current students, create a network of diverse experiences and skills, represent the best output of our alma mater. 
 
 
What we do 
 
We organize scientific seminars and conferences (once a week during the school year) and orientation activities. We mentor current students. We organize social events. 
 
 
My role and responsibilities 
 
As a President, I run and lead the organization of all the events and activities; I interact with the academic and students representatives; I organize an yearly fund-raising campaign to support the Association activities; I interact with all the alumni members to involve, motivate, and support their active participation; I am the administrator of the Association website, Facebook and LinkedIn groups, Twitter and YouTube accounts. Chief Organizer TEDxSSC April 2014  –  October 2014  (7 months) TEDxSSC - Dall'eccezione alla regola (From the exception to the rule) 
 
Leading the entire organization of a TEDx event (100+ guests, 20+ speakers, 18 organizing 
team members, $20k budget). 
 
TED is a world-wide recognized brand ensuring high quality talks, speakers and ideas. As a President of the SSC Alumni Association, along with the Student Association and the academic leaders, we decided to bring TED experience in our institution and community through TEDxSSC. In fact, many of the TEDx values match our institution values (interdisciplinarity, fostering new ideas, spreading innovation and creativity). TEDx mission is to communicate the power of ideas to change attitudes, lives and, ultimately, the world. We want to demonstrate how uncommon ideas and people (the exceptions) can make a real difference, change the world and set a new standard for our everyday life. We have chosen an extremely fascinating theme: “Dall’eccezione alla regola” (“From the exception to the standard”). Our speakers will be unheard local voices as well as known personalities. We will select our list of speakers choosing those people that can tell their personal story as an example of something first considered an exception, then becoming a new standard. Experience Postdoctoral Scholar Stanford University April 2007  –  October 2010  (3 years 7 months) I am a postdoctoral scholar studying neuroscience at Stanford University. I am working in Tirin Moore's laboratory studying the neural basis of vison. I use a combination of physiological and computational techniques to investigate how neurons in the brain encode information about visual world that can be used to guide behavior. Currently my focus is on understanding how neurons in frontal cortex (a region of the brain critical for complex cognitive functioning) can integrate visual information over time to create the persistent internal representations required for goal-driven behaviors. This work lies at the intersection of sensory processing and memory, two functions that are most often studied in isolation, despite the fact that in daily life they are often intertwined. Laboratory Instructor Princeton University January 2003  –  May 2003  (5 months) Led a weekly lab section for an undergraduate course on cognitive neuroscience. Activities included giving brief presentations on relevant course material, answering student questions, leading experimental exercises in neuroanatomy and perception, and editing and grading student term papers. Software Design Engineer Intern Microsoft - Macintosh Power Point Division June 2000  –  August 2000  (3 months) During my time at Microsoft I developed a "print preview" capability for a program that integrated several features of Power Point into a software package for graphics design and illustration. I used CodeWarrior development tools to design and test my project, which was created in C++. Teaching Assistant - Introduction to Computing University of Michigan College of Engineering August 1999  –  December 1999  (5 months) Led a weekly discussion section for an introductory electrical engineering and computer science class. Course material covered fundamentals of digital representations, computer architecture and assembly coding, and C programming. Activities included designing and giving presentations to summarize the week's lectures and to give added emphasis to important concepts, to address student questions, provide consultation on problem sets, and prepare and lead review sessions before exams. Web Development Assistant University of Michigan Hospitals - Radiation Oncology May 1999  –  August 1999  (4 months) Developed a web site that allowed doctors to securely access a database of patient scheduling information remotely. Self-taught web page development including HTML and server-side scripting using Microsoft Active Server Pages. Summary I'm an Assistant Professor in the Department of Economics at Boise State University. I'm an applied social scientist - an economist by training - working on issues of urbanization, global environmental change and sustainability. My work has touched upon several topics; among a few, urban land use change modeling and its policy relevance, the evolution of urban landscape patterns and the bi-directional interactions of urban spatial structure with the environment, urban land teleconnections, urban ecology and environmental justice, urban infrastructure and vulnerability. I teach various courses: Microeconomics, Economics of Sustainability, Quantitative Methods and Econometrics.  
 
Have served as a lead author in two large assessment reports including the 'UN-CBD Cities and Biodiversity Outlook' and the '2013 National Climate Assessment' of the US Global Change Research Program. I have also been a contributing author in the Fifth Assessment Report of the IPCC. 
 
Specialties: Urbanization; global environmental change/environmental studies; quantitative research methods, geospatial technologies (GIS and remote sensing); sustainability; data visualization 
 
Past work: Between 2006 and 2012 I was the Executive Officer of the International Human Dimensions Programme's (IHDP) core project on Urbanization and Global Environmental Change (UGEC), based at Arizona State University in Tempe, Arizona, U.S.A. From 2003 to 2006 I was a postdoctoral scholar at Stanford University at the Center for Environmental Science and Policy at the Freeman-Spogli Institute for International Studies. I hold Ph.D. in Economics - with a focus on economic geography and the environment - from Clark University in Massachusetts, U.S.A. Summary I study practice-based designs for teacher education focusing particularly on how teacher educators attend to their social justice commitments when designing for practice. Before beginning my current position as a postdoctoral scholar at Stanford University, I received my doctorate from the University of Washington where I led a team in the development of Teacher Education by Design (TEDD.org) a web-based, free-content library of practice-based tools for teacher educators. I come to research from a career as a middle and high school teacher of English Language Arts and History and a curriculum designer for the New York Times Learning Network. Experience Postdoctoral Scholar Stanford University January 2015  – Present (8 months) Stanford, CA In my position as a postdoctoral scholar at the Center to Support Excellence in Teaching at Stanford University my research is focused on practice-based pedagogical approaches to professional development for early-career teachers.  Ph.D. Candidate University of Washington September 2009  –  January 2015  (5 years 5 months) My dissertation study is a comparative case study examining social justice teaching practices. I am examining these practices through the lens of one case of social justice teaching, LGBTQ-support. The study follows four LGBTQ-supportive teachers through a year of teaching as they engage in a set of practices aimed at disrupting the inequities that disadvantage LGBTQ students. 
 
While a doctoral candidate at the University of Washington, I worked on various research and development projects: I led the team that developed Teacher Education by Design, or TEDD.org, an open-source library of practice-based tools for teacher education and professional development. Along with developing TEDD.org, I worked on the design teams of two new practice-based teacher education programs: U-ACT and a redesign of Teach for America's summer institute in Chicago. In addition, I taught three graduate-level courses in the College of Education: (1) Multicultural Teaching, a course for pre-service secondary teacher candidates in all disciplines, (2) Humanities Methods, a course for Language Arts and Social Studies middle and high school teachers in their first year as classroom teachers, and (3) Justice in Practice, a course for elementary teaching candidates that brought practice-based methods pedagogies to a foundations course in multicultural education. In addition, I taught three graduate-level courses in the College of Education: (1) Multicultural Teaching, a course for pre-service secondary teacher candidates in all disciplines, (2) Humanities Methods, a course for Language Arts and Social Studies middle and high school teachers in their first year as classroom teachers, and (3) Justice in Practice, a course for elementary teaching candidates that brought practice-based methods pedagogies to a foundations course in multicultural education. Summary I am an astrophysicist and cosmologist studying how the Universe formed and why its expansion is suddenly accelerating. Day-to-day, I use supercomputers, data from large imaging surveys of the night sky and lots of code in Python and C to study these problems.  
 
I am currently a Postdoctoral Scholar at Stanford University in the Department of Physics and Kavli Institute for Particle Astrophysics and Cosmology. Additionally, I work heavily on the Dark Energy Survey. Summary I am an astrophysicist and cosmologist studying how the Universe formed and why its expansion is suddenly accelerating.
